   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure and hypotension.
   .
   #) SVT: pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was
   hemodynamically unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on
   levophed. In terms of etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to
   infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - cardioversion when pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS. Unsure whether GBS would give a toxic
   shock syndrome picture and lead to ARDS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis
   in lungs less likely given no blood seen on bronch, stable HCT.
   ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on PC, will decr RR further as pt appears to have autoPEEP and not
   able to breath out completely, and repeat ABG
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - on acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - Discontinued vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl.
   - restarted acyclovir 10 mg/kg IV q 8 hours for empiric therapy.
   - f/u on Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody; Anaplasma phagocytophilum (human
   granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For Parasites;
   Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella
   zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdoment if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo.
   - changed levophed to neo in the setting of SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - monitor UOP, MAP, CVP
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Acid/base disturbances: gap closed. Continues to mild non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic
   acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct has been trending down, received 2u pRBC yesterday. On
   admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive,
   anemia of chronic disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate.
   Fe studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and
   folate are normal. No evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point.
   Patient also has renal failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - pt received 2u pRBC yesterday, Hct appropriately bumped. Goal Hct >30
   as he has SVT
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.0. Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and
   ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would consider that
   possibility given his picture of respiratory failure, renal failure,
   vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - renally dose medications
   - repeat UA urine lytes, consider renal consult if renal function
   continues to worse
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine

   #) Hypernatremia: Resolved. Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during
   diuresis.
   - continue  free water flushes to 250cc q3h
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: this morning was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), was

   - continue to monitor on tele

   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 84-year-old male who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. The patient has undergone several cardioversions and defibrillations due to supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has bilateral infiltrate on CXR and CT evidence of left lower lobe consolidation, consistent with hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). He has a sputum culture that grew out non-group A strep and OSH sputum was positive with GBS.
2. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, and the source of infection is likely pulmonary given the CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia.
3. Acid-base disturbances: The patient has mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
4. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, and his Hct has been trending down. He received 2u pRBC yesterday, and his goal Hct is >30.
5. Rash: The patient has a diffuse rash, which is likely secondary to toxic shock syndrome. He was started on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production and triamcinolone ointment for skin rash.
6. Renal failure: The patient has Cr trending up 1.9-3.0, likely due to ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given the negative ANCA and [**Doctor First Name **].
7. Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status likely due to sedation and prolonged sepsis. He has no corneal or pupil reflexes, but he does move extremities to pain.
8. Hypernatremia: The patient had hypernatremia, which resolved likely due to volume depletion during diuresis.
9. Transaminitis: The patient had transaminitis, which resolved, and his liver synthetic function is good.
10. Afib with RVR: The patient was in SVT this morning, which was cardioverted.

The patient's goals of care include:

1. Update family
2. Continue ICU care
3. Monitor and manage his medical complications
4. Improve his respiratory status
5. Manage his sepsis and underlying infections
6. Improve his renal function
7. Manage his acid-base disturbances
8. Monitor his anemia and transfusion requirements
9. Manage his rash and skin lesions
10. Monitor his mental status and neurological function

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Development of multi-organ failure
2. Worsening of his respiratory status
3. Progression of his sepsis and underlying infections
4. Decrease in his renal function
5. Worsening of his acid-base disturbances
6. Further decline in his mental status and neurological function
7. Development of new skin lesions or rashes
8. Increased risk of bleeding or thrombosis due to his coagulopathy
9. Development of new infections or complications related to his underlying conditions.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of throat cancer, pneumonia, and respiratory failure. They have a diffuse rash and are intubated, sedated, and unresponsive. The patient has been experiencing supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and has received cardioversion three times. They are on multiple medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and bronchodilators. The patient's vital signs are stable, but they have a history of anemia and have received a blood transfusion.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged intubation and respiratory failure make them susceptible to VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and rash increase their risk of developing sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of SVT and cardioversion increase their risk of developing other cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying respiratory disease and pneumonia increase their risk of developing respiratory failure, which could lead to a decline in their overall condition.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen if they continue to lose blood or have inadequate transfusion support.
6. Infection: The patient's diffuse rash and pneumonia increase their risk of developing other infections, such as urinary tract infections or bloodstream infections.
7. Organ dysfunction: The patient's underlying disease and prolonged ICU stay increase their risk of developing organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury or liver failure.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a diagnosis of throat cancer, resp failure due to pneumonia, and a diffuse rash. The patient has been experiencing supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and has undergone cardioversion three times.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 66 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 100/38 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PC mode of 20/12, PEEP of 12 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 40%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) values are:

* pH: 7.28
* PaO2: 253 mmHg
* PaCO2: 34 mmHg
* HCO3-: 101 mmol/L
* BE: -9 mmol/L

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 15.0 K/uL
* Platelet count: 125 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.03 ng/mL
* Glucose: 105 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals a diffuse rash, distant lung sounds, and no wheezing.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Throat cancer (inactive issue)
* Pneumonia (resp failure)
* Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)
* Anemia (transfused yesterday)
* COPD (cont bronchodilators)
* HSV (cont acyclovir)

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue antibiotics for pneumonia
* Wean vent as tolerated
* Monitor for signs of sepsis
* Continue acyclovir for HSV
* Monitor for signs of anemia
* Continue bronchodilators for COPD
* Monitor for signs of resp failure

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis due to pneumonia or other underlying infections
* Respiratory failure due to inadequate ventilation or worsening pneumonia
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to SVT or other underlying cardiac conditions
* Anemia due to ongoing blood loss or inadequate transfusion
* Infection due to HSV or other underlying infections
* Worsening of COPD due to inadequate bronchodilator therapy

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities. The patient has undergone cardioversion and defibrillation multiple times due to supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 66 beats per minute, blood pressure of 100/38 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%.

The patient has been diagnosed with hypernatremia (high sodium), hypotension, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or acute lung injury (ALI). The patient also has a rash, which is likely an allergic reaction to one of the medications. The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, lactate, and creatinine, indicating possible cardiac and renal damage.

The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a pressure-controlled mode, and the patient is receiving oxygen therapy. The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, and the patient is receiving vasopressors to support blood pressure.

The patient's medical history includes throat cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and human herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The patient also has anemia, which may be contributing to the patient's hypotension.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of SVT and cardioversion/defibrillation may indicate a risk of further cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS/ALI may progress to respiratory failure, requiring further mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
3. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and possible cardiac damage may indicate a risk of renal failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient's rash and elevated lactate levels may indicate a risk of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis may not be adequate, and the patient may be at risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and presence of central lines may increase the risk of DVT.
7. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of VAP.

To address these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory failure, and renal failure. The patient's fluid balance and vasopressor therapy should be carefully managed to prevent further cardiac damage. The patient's rash should be treated with appropriate antibiotics, and the patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis should be re-evaluated. The patient's nutritional needs should be assessed and addressed, and the patient's glycemic control should be monitored to prevent hyperglycemia.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a history of cardiac arrest, respiratory distress, and acute kidney injury. The patient has undergone multiple cardioversions and defibrillations due to supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 66 bpm, blood pressure of 100/38 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 0 mL and a PEEP of 12 cmH2O. The patient's laboratory results show elevated sodium levels, hypotension, and impaired skin integrity. The patient's respiratory status is critical, with an acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) diagnosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of SVT and cardioversions/defibrillations increases the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS diagnosis and need for mechanical ventilation increase the risk of respiratory failure, including hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
3. Sepsis: The patient's history of antibiotic administration and elevated white blood cell count increase the risk of sepsis, including septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury and history of hypotension increase the risk of renal failure, including oliguria and acute tubular necrosis.
5. Skin breakdown: The patient's impaired skin integrity increases the risk of skin breakdown, including pressure ulcers and skin infections.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of stress ulcer prophylaxis and elevated lactate levels increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, including upper gastrointestinal bleeding and melena.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and hypotension increase the risk of neurological complications, including cerebral edema, seizures, and stroke.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust therapy as needed to prevent cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Optimize the patient's respiratory status by adjusting ventilator settings and considering non-invasive ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed to prevent hyperglycemia.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluid and electrolyte therapy as needed to prevent renal failure.
5. Implement measures to prevent skin breakdown, including turning and repositioning the patient every 2 hours and using pressure-reducing mattresses.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding risk and consider prophylactic antacids or histamine-2 blockers if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status and consider imaging studies or electroencephalograms (EEGs) if neurological symptoms develop.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of throat cancer, respiratory failure due to pneumonia, and supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). The patient has been treated with various antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefipime, and metronidazole. They have also received midazolam, fentanyl, and phenylephrine infusions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 66 bpm, blood pressure of 100/38 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube and mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition. The patient's CXR shows slightly worse bibasilar infiltrates, indicating that the pneumonia may be worsening.
2. Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT): The patient's SVT is a serious arrhythmia that can increase the risk of cardiac complications. The patient has received cardioversion/defibrillation treatments, but the SVT persists.
3. Hypernatremia (High Sodium): The patient's sodium level is elevated, which can lead to dehydration, seizures, and other complications.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which can reduce blood flow to vital organs and increase the risk of organ damage.
5. Rash: The patient has a rash, which may be a sign of an allergic reaction or an underlying infection.
6. Throat Cancer: The patient's throat cancer is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition that requires ongoing treatment and monitoring.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be contributing to their respiratory failure and other complications.
8. COPD: The patient's COPD may be exacerbating their respiratory failure and increasing their risk of complications.
9. HSV: The patient's HSV infection may be contributing to their respiratory failure and other complications.
10. DVT: The patient is at risk of developing a DVT due to their immobility and other risk factors.

Overall, the patient is at risk of developing serious medical complications, including pneumonia, SVT, hypernatremia, hypotension, and DVT. The patient requires ongoing monitoring and treatment to manage these complications and improve their condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT), Hypernatremia (high sodium), Hypotension (not in shock), Impaired Skin Integrity, and Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure of 108/39 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and vasopressors. They are also receiving IV fluids, including NovaSource Renal, and have an arterial line and multi-lumen line in place.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, indicating possible sepsis or inflammation. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with elevated sodium and potassium levels.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and LDH levels suggest possible sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS diagnosis puts them at risk for respiratory failure, which can require mechanical ventilation and other supportive care.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's supraventricular tachycardia and hypotension may indicate underlying cardiovascular instability, which can worsen with further stress.
4. Skin breakdown: The patient's impaired skin integrity increases their risk for skin breakdown and pressure ulcers, which can lead to infection and other complications.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's abnormal electrolyte levels can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications if not managed properly.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical condition. The patient has been diagnosed with Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT) and has been managed with cardioversion and pressor support. The patient's rash is likely related to toxic shock syndrome and is being managed with supportive care.

The patient's respiratory status remains critical, with high ventilator requirements and a need for ongoing antibiotic therapy. The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, with a total fluid intake of 4,523 mL and a total output of 1,196 mL over the past 24 hours.

The patient's laboratory results show signs of kidney dysfunction, with a creatinine level of 3.2 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 17 mg/dL. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 20 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 20 IU/L.

The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a potassium level of 3.8 mEq/L and a sodium level of 138 mEq/L. The patient's blood glucose level is stable, with a level of 124 mg/dL.

The patient's chest X-ray (CXR) shows some improvement in the bilateral basilar opacities, but the patient's respiratory status remains critical.

Potential medical complications that may arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's high ventilator requirements and ongoing antibiotic therapy make them at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's rash and elevated white blood cell count (WBC) make them at risk for sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine level and BUN level make them at risk for AKI.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient's mildly elevated LFTs make them at risk for liver dysfunction.
5. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but may become imbalanced due to ongoing fluid and electrolyte management.
6. Infection: The patient's ongoing antibiotic therapy and risk of sepsis make them at risk for infection.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status. The patient's fluid and electrolyte management should be closely monitored, and the patient should be considered for further diagnostic testing, such as an echocardiogram or a head CT scan, to further evaluate their condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities and complex medical conditions. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and sedatives, to manage their condition.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate of 67 beats per minute (bpm), and blood pressure of 108/39 mmHg. Their respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and troponin-T, indicating possible inflammation and cardiac injury. The patient's blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are elevated, suggesting acute kidney injury (AKI). The patient's electrolyte levels, including potassium, sodium, and chloride, are within normal limits.

The patient's imaging studies, including a chest X-ray (CXR), show some improvement in the bilateral basal opacities, indicating possible resolution of pneumonia.

The patient's medical conditions include supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), rash, pneumonia, acute respiratory failure (ARF), throat cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), herpes simplex virus (HSV), and anemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: SVT can progress to more severe arrhythmias, such as ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia, which can be life-threatening.
2. Respiratory failure: Pneumonia and ARF can worsen, leading to further respiratory distress and the need for mechanical ventilation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC and LDH levels suggest possible sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated BUN and creatinine levels indicate AKI, which can worsen if not managed promptly.
5. Throat cancer progression: The patient's inactive throat cancer can progress, leading to further complications and potential spread to other parts of the body.
6. HSV reactivation: The patient's ongoing treatment with acyclovir may not be sufficient to prevent HSV reactivation, which can lead to further complications, such as encephalitis or meningitis.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed promptly, leading to further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or respiratory failure.

Based on these findings, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve their outcome.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT), respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (ARF), and anemia. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and has a diffuse rash. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 67 bpm, and blood pressure of 108/39 mmHg. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and pressors.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Severe sepsis and septic shock due to the diffuse rash and possibility of toxic shock syndrome.
2. Respiratory failure and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation.
3. Acute kidney injury (ARF) and need for renal replacement therapy (RRT) due to the patient's worsening renal function.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias, including supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), which may require cardioversion.
5. Infection and sepsis due to the patient's immunocompromised state and prolonged hospitalization.
6. Malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances due to the patient's inability to eat and the use of total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to the patient's immobility and prolonged hospitalization.
8. Stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's critical illness and use of pressors.
9. Non-gap acidosis and metabolic acidosis due to the patient's underlying disease and use of medications.
10. Potential for medication interactions and side effects due to the patient's complex medication regimen.

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure and hypotension.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS. Unsure whether GBS would give a toxic
   shock syndrome picture and lead to ARDS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis
   in lungs less likely given no blood seen on bronch, stable HCT.
   ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on PC, will decr RR further as pt appears to have autoPEEP and not
   able to breath out completely, and repeat ABG
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection - f/u on Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody;
   Anaplasma phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM;
   Blood Smear For Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus
   B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdoment if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo.
   - changed levophed to neo in the setting of SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - monitor UOP, MAP, CVP
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) SVT: pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was
   hemodynamically unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on
   levophed. In terms of etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to
   infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - cardioversion when pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   .
   #) Acid/base disturbances: gap closed. Continues to mild non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic
   acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct has been trending down, received 2u pRBC yesterday. On
   admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive,
   anemia of chronic disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate.
   Fe studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and
   folate are normal. No evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point.
   Patient also has renal failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - pt received 2u pRBC yesterday, Hct appropriately bumped. Goal Hct >30
   as he has SVT
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and
   ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would consider that
   possibility given his picture of respiratory failure, renal failure,
   vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - renally dose medications
   - repeat UA urine lytes, consider renal consult if renal function
   continues to worse
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Resolved. Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during
   diuresis.
   - continue  free water flushes to 250cc q3h
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: this morning was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), was
   condioverted
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was improving until Saturday when his mental status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has LLL consolidation on CXR and CT, consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep, and OSH sputum was positive with GBS. The patient is on PC, and his RR is being decreased further as he appears to have autoPEEP and not able to breathe out completely.
2. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, and the source of infection is likely pulmonary given the CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other potential sources of infection include GI, but no evidence of GI infection is currently present.
3. Hypotension: The patient is likely experiencing hypotension secondary to sepsis from underlying lung infection. He is currently on neo and is being monitored for UOP, MAP, CVP, and cultures.
4. SVT: The patient was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT, which is likely secondary to infection, volume depletion, and levophed.
5. Acid-base disturbances: The patient has a mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
6. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is likely secondary to GIB, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, or DAH. He has received 2u pRBC yesterday and his Hct has been trending down.
7. Rash: The patient has a diffuse rash, which is likely related to toxic shock syndrome or leukoclastic vasculitis.
8. Renal failure: The patient has renal failure, which is likely secondary to ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given the negative ANCA and ANCA.
9. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely secondary to sedation and prolonged sepsis.
10. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia has resolved, likely secondary to volume depletion during diuresis.
11. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis has resolved, and his liver synthetic function is good.
12. Afib with RVR: The patient was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT) this morning, which was cardioverted.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can continue to deteriorate, leading to further respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can worsen, leading to organ failure and increased risk of mortality.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can worsen, leading to decreased perfusion and organ damage.
4. SVT: The patient's SVT can recur, leading to further cardiac instability.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Rash: The patient's rash can continue to worsen, leading to increased risk of infection and organ damage.
7. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure can worsen, leading to increased risk of mortality.
8. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status can worsen, leading to decreased ability to communicate and increased risk of complications.
9. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia can recur, leading to increased risk of complications.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following goals of care should be prioritized:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure and sepsis.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's anemia and renal failure.
4. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's rash and skin lesions.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust therapy as necessary.
7. Continue to provide supportive care, including nutrition and glycemic control.

It is essential to continue to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent further complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. He was transferred to the ICU for management of respiratory failure and is currently in multi-organ failure (pulmonary, cardiac, renal, and dermatological).

The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including:

1. Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation, consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH sputum was positive with GBS. The patient is being treated with penicillin G, clindamycin, and cipro.
2. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, and his source of infection is likely pulmonary. He is being treated with antibiotics and fluids.
3. Hypotension: The patient is likely in septic shock and is being treated with vasopressors.
4. SVT: The patient had an episode of SVT, which was likely secondary to infection, volume depletion, and levophed. He was cardioverted and is currently being monitored.
5. Anemia: The patient has a mild anemia, which is likely secondary to chronic disease/inflammation, gastrointestinal bleeding, or acute on chronic renal failure.
6. Rash: The patient has a diffuse rash, which is likely secondary to toxic shock syndrome or leukoclastic vasculitis. He is being treated with clindamycin and acyclovir.
7. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, which is likely secondary to hypotension from sepsis. He is being treated with fluids and renal-dosed medications.
8. Altered mental status: The patient is likely in a state of sedation and prolonged sepsis. He is being monitored for any changes in his mental status.

Potential medical complications:

1. Worsening respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status could deteriorate further, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Worsening sepsis: The patient's sepsis could worsen, leading to multi-organ failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status could deteriorate further, leading to cardiac arrest or cardiogenic shock.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal function could worsen, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Skin complications: The patient's skin rash could worsen, leading to skin breakdown or infection.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status could worsen, leading to neurological deficits or coma.

The patient's family should be involved in discussing his goals of care, as he has a low chance of recovering to his baseline state.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was admitted to the hospital with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has a CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation, consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH sputum was positive with GBS. The patient is on AC currently and will continue penicillin G, clindamycin, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
* Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, and his WBC is trending down. The source of infection is likely pulmonary given the CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to sepsis from underlying lung infection. He is currently on neo and will continue to treat underlying infection.
* SVT: The patient's SVT is likely secondary to infection, volume depletion, and levophed. Cardioversion will be considered if the patient goes back into SVT with hemodynamic instability.
* Acid-base disturbances: The patient has a mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and acute on chronic renal failure.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to GIB, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, or DAH. He received 2u PRBC on [**8-6**].
* Rash: The patient has a diffuse rash, which is likely due to GBS, generalized pustulosis, or a flare of psoriasis. He is on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production and acyclovir for HSV infection.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely due to ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given negative ANCA and ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen, it would be considered.
* Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to sedation and prolonged sepsis. He is currently sedated and has no corneal or pupil reflexes.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia has resolved, likely due to volume depletion during diuresis.
* Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis has resolved, and his liver synthetic function is good.
* Afib with RVR: The patient's Afib with RVR has resolved, and he is currently in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT).

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to HAP, and he may require mechanical ventilation.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* SVT: The patient's SVT may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
* Acid-base disturbances: The patient's acid-base disturbances may lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Rash: The patient's rash may lead to skin lesions and infection.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may lead to end-stage renal disease.
* Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may lead to neurological damage and disability.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
* Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may lead to liver failure.
* Afib with RVR: The patient's Afib with RVR may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.

The patient's goals of care include:

* Family meeting on Tuesday
* ICU care
* Nutrition: tube feeds
* Glycemic control: ISS
* Lines: arterial line, multi-lumen line
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, VAP

The patient's code status is DNR, and cardioversion is OK.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure, complicated by persistent sepsis, worsening renal failure, and a large left-sided effusion. The patient has been treated with maximal medical therapy, including antibiotics and vasopressors, but continues to deteriorate.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's persistent hypoxemic respiratory failure increases the risk of further respiratory deterioration, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and acute lung injury.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if not effectively managed, leading to multi-organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
3. Renal failure: The patient's worsening renal failure increases the risk of acute tubular necrosis (ATN), which can lead to chronic kidney disease and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's high sodium levels can lead to complications such as seizures, coma, and even death if not managed promptly.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension increases the risk of organ hypoperfusion and failure, particularly in the kidneys and liver.
6. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's rash and skin lesions increase the risk of infection and further complications.
7. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure increases the risk of developing ARDS, which can lead to significant morbidity and mortality.

To manage these potential complications, the patient should continue to receive maximal medical therapy, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and respiratory support. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory values, and imaging studies is essential to detect any worsening of his condition.

   - f/u on ID recs
   .

   down, and fever curve going down as well. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree

   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.

   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.

   - avoid levophed given recent SVT

d as possibly

t have another episode during the past 24 hours. pt was

   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was admitted to the ICU with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has been diagnosed with group B strep pneumonia, and is being treated with antibiotics. He has also been diagnosed with sepsis, and is being treated with vasopressors to maintain blood pressure. He has a history of smoking and is at risk for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.4, and a lactate level of 2.1 mmol/L. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 114 mg/dL, and his creatinine level is 3.2 mg/dL. His albumin level is 1.7 g/dL, and his total protein level is 6.8 g/dL. His hemoglobin level is 9.0 g/dL, and his hematocrit is 28.3%.

The patient's physical examination shows a diffuse rash, and his skin is tender to the touch. He has a fever, and his blood pressure is 102/33 mmHg. His heart rate is 65 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 100%, and his end-tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) level is 34 mmHg.

The patient's medical history includes a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a history of smoking. He has also been diagnosed with group B strep pneumonia, and is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient's medications include:

* Acyclovir
* Penicillin G
* Clindamycin
* Ciprofloxacin
* Doxycycline
* Vasopressin
* Levophed
* Midazolam
* Fentanyl
* Pantoprazole
* Heparin sodium

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a diagnosis of sepsis, and is at risk for further complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is at risk for further decline in renal function.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is unstable, and he is at risk for further cardiovascular instability.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status is a concern, and he is at risk for further neurological complications.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of smoking and COPD puts him at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Skin complications: The patient's diffuse rash is a concern, and he is at risk for further skin complications, such as infection or necrosis.

The patient's goals of care include:

* Family meeting on Tuesday
* ICU care
* Nutrition: NovaSource Renal (Full)
* Glycemic control: ISS
* Lines: Arterial line, multi-lumen line
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, VAP
* Comments: Code status: DNR, cardioversion is OK
* Disposition: ICU care

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure, and now in multi-organ failure
   (pulm, cardiac/SVT, renal, derm)
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's
   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less
   likely- ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on  AC currently today
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production, and cipro (day 1: [**8-3**]) for
   gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this
   presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - added doxy per ID recs (day1: [**8-8**])
   - f/u cultures here and from OSH
   - if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. However, WBC trending
   down, and fever curve going down as well. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody neg; f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma phagocytophilum
   (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For
   Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies;
   Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo and vasopressin.
   - avoid levophed given recent SVT
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: gap 11, albumin 1.7, so continues to have an
   anion gap, likely due to renal failure. Delta delta 0.52, so also has a
   non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic
   metabolic acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. has stablized.  Most
   likely [**12-21**] ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely
   given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would
   consider that possibility given his picture of respiratory failure,
   renal failure, vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - consider renal consult if renal function continues to worse
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p free water
   flushes q6h. now hyponatremic.
   - d/c free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 24 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct >30 as he has SVT
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family mtg Tuesday
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2100-8-9**] 07:00 PM 35 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

   DVT: SC heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Patient's Condition:**

* The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status.
* He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension.
* He is currently in multi-organ failure (pulmonary, cardiac, renal, and dermatological).
* His laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, renal failure, metabolic acidosis, and anemia.
* He has a diffuse rash, worsening, petechial rash on his back and dependent areas, and perioral lesions.
* He has a history of smoking and is at risk for COPD.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Sepsis: The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, and his clinical picture suggests that he may have a pulmonary source of infection.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's CXR and CT scans show evidence of LLL consolidation, consistent with HAP.
* Cardiac instability: The patient has been experiencing hypotension and has required vasopressors to maintain blood pressure.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he has been diagnosed with acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to renal failure.
* Anemia: The patient has a stable Hct, but his anemia is likely due to GIB, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, or DAH.
* Dermatological complications: The patient has a diffuse rash, petechial rash on his back and dependent areas, and perioral lesions, which may be related to GBS, generalized pustulosis, or psoriasis.
* Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status, which may be due to sedation, prolonged sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient was started on levothyroxine, but it is unclear if he truly has hypothyroidism or sick euthyroid syndrome.

**Plan:**

* Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and vasopressors.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider intubation if necessary.
* Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with fluid resuscitation and renal-dose medications.
* Monitor the patient's metabolic acidosis and consider treating with bicarbonate if necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusing if necessary.
* Monitor the patient's dermatological complications and consider treating with topical corticosteroids or other medications as necessary.
* Monitor the patient's neurological status and consider treating with sedatives or other medications as necessary.
* Consider checking thyroid function tests if the patient's condition improves.

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure, and now in multi-organ failure
   (pulm, cardiac/SVT, renal, derm)
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's
   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less
   likely- ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on  AC currently today
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day4), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day3) to
   inhibit toxin production, and cipro (day 6) for gram-negative
   coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection, as per ID this presentation
   could represent HSV generalized infection
   - added doxy per ID recs
   - f/u cultures here and from OSH
   - if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. However, WBC trending
   down, and fever curve going down as well. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody neg; f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma phagocytophilum
   (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For
   Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies;
   Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo and vasopressin.
   - avoid levophed given recent SVT
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: gap 11, albumin 1.7, so continues to have an
   anion gap, likely due to renal failure. Delta delta 0.52, so also has a
   non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic
   metabolic acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. has stablized.  Most
   likely [**12-21**] ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely
   given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would
   consider that possibility given his picture of respiratory failure,
   renal failure, vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - consider renal consult if renal function continues to worse
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p free water
   flushes q6h. now hyponatremic.
   - d/c free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 24 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct >30 as he has SVT
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family mtg Tuesday
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2100-8-9**] 07:00 PM 35 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of throat cancer and is at risk for COPD. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure. The CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation suggests a possible diagnosis of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).
2. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, and the source of infection is likely pulmonary given the CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. The patient's WBC trend is down, and his fever curve is also decreasing, suggesting that the infection is being treated effectively.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he is currently on vasopressin and neo to maintain blood pressure. The etiology of hypotension is likely sepsis, and the patient's renal function is stable.
4. Renal failure: The patient has chronic kidney disease, and his renal function is stable, but he is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypotension and sepsis.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has an anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely due to renal failure. He is also at risk for hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis due to the use of IV fluids.
6. Skin rash: The patient has a diffuse rash, which is likely related to toxic shock syndrome or generalized pustulosis. The rash is worsening, and the patient is at risk for further complications.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is likely due to chronic kidney disease, inflammation, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Altered mental status: The patient is sedated and has altered mental status, which is likely due to sedation and prolonged sepsis.
9. Transaminitis: The patient had transaminitis, which has resolved, but he is at risk for further liver dysfunction due to his underlying medical conditions.
10. Hypothyroidism: The patient was started on levothyroxine, but it is unclear if he truly has hypothyroidism or sick euthyroid syndrome. He is at risk for further thyroid dysfunction due to his underlying medical conditions.

The patient's goals of care include:

1. Family meeting on Tuesday
2. ICU care
3. Nutrition: NovaSource Renal (Full)
4. Glycemic control: ISS
5. Lines: arterial line, multi-lumen line
6. Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, VAP
7. Code status: DNR, cardioversion is OK
8. Disposition: ICU care

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure, and now with renal failure as well.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out GBS.  Patient received
   lots of IVF yesterday for hypotension, and this AM the CXR appeared
   more volume overloaded. TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's
   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less
   likely- ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on  AC currently, will decrease rate from 24 to 18, and monitor ABG
   to see if ventilation adequate
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production, and cipro (day 1: [**8-3**]) for
   gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this
   presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - added doxy per ID recs (day1: [**8-8**]);  if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy
   - f/u cultures here and from OSH
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody neg; f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma phagocytophilum
   (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For
   Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies;
   Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal SBP>85 (not , UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and
   ScvO2 >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo and vasopressin.
   - add levophed if continues to be hypotensive after IVF boluses
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: gap 11, albumin 1.7, so continues to have an
   anion gap, likely due to renal failure. Delta delta 0.52, so also has a
   non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic
   metabolic acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. has stablized.  Most
   likely [**12-21**] ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely
   given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would
   consider that possibility given his picture of respiratory failure,
   renal failure, vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - consider renal consult if renal function continues to worse
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p free water
   flushes q6h. now hyponatremic.
   - d/c free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 24 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct >30 as he has SVT
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:

   ICU Care
