   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   renal failure and altered mental status.
   #) Respiratory failure: Initial CXR and CT evidence of LLL
   consolidation, consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out GBS.
   Patient has been treated with penicillin G and clinda, and his
   pneumonia is improving on imaging. TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF.
   Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV
   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip). This respiratory
   failure could potentially be secondary to generalized HSV infection,
   the HSV DFA and culture from mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers
   to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis,
   bilateral pleural effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.
   - on  AC currently, RR increased from 18 to 22 in an attempt to blow
   off CO2 when he is being given bicarb
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this
   presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue doxy (day1: [**8-8**]);  if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 today, re-check lytes in the
   pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, can give another
   dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal. Other source of infection includes
   GI but no evidence of GI infection at this time, no diarrhea noted. KUB
   on [**8-3**] showed small amount of pericholecystic fluid, but no
   cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt is intermittently
   hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree of bowel ischemia
   leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a coccyx ulcer but the
   wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has been negative, and
   TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
   get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - will aggressively resuscitate with LR.  wean down pressors as pt has
   evidence of digital ischemia now. Goal MAP 55 (given his very low
   diastolic), although it would still be ideal to get his MAP to 65 to
   adequately perfuse his brain for improvement in mental status
   - hope to decrease his pressor requirements when metabolic acidosis
   improves on bicarb
   - goal I/O at least 1 liter positive as pt has lots of insensible fluid
   loss from skin
   - goal UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2 >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have an anion gap, likely due to
   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly
   improved.
   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 22  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   - continue to follow renal function and lactate levels
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**]. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating skin lesions, renal failure, and altered mental status. He has been diagnosed with GBS pneumonia and HSV infection. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a complex medical condition with multiple organ dysfunction, including sepsis, metabolic acidosis, renal failure, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and the presence of bilateral pleural effusion and pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress and lead to multi-organ failure, including cardiac, renal, and hepatic failure.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen due to his underlying kidney disease and the presence of lactic acidosis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may worsen due to his underlying kidney disease and the presence of sepsis.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to his underlying chronic disease and the presence of bleeding.
6. Skin lesions: The patient's skin lesions may worsen due to his underlying skin disease and the presence of HSV infection.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability may worsen due to his underlying heart disease and the presence of sepsis.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological complications, including altered mental status and stereotypical decorticate reflexes, may worsen due to his underlying brain disease and the presence of sepsis.
9. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing additional infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and wound infection.
10. Bleeding: The patient is at risk of bleeding due to his underlying bleeding disorder and the presence of sepsis.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The patient's respiratory status, cardiovascular status, and neurological status should be closely monitored and managed accordingly. The patient's metabolic acidosis should be managed with bicarbonate therapy, and his renal failure should be managed with fluid resuscitation and diuretic therapy. The patient's anemia should be managed with transfusion therapy, and his skin lesions should be managed with wound care and topical therapy. The patient's cardiovascular instability should be managed with pressor therapy, and his neurological complications should be managed with sedation and pain management. The patient's infection should be managed with antibiotics, and his bleeding should be managed with transfusion therapy and hemostatic agents.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, sepsis, and multiorgan failure. The patient has a history of GBS sepsis, pneumonia, and HSV infection.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated with a PRVC/AC mode, with a Vt of 550 mL and a RR of 22. The patient's oxygenation is improving, but there is still marginal MS acidosis, which is a barrier to weaning.
* Sepsis: The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, including PCN, Clindamycin, and Acyclovir. The patient's septic shock has remained pressor-dependent, and the goal is to maintain a MAP of >55.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is unchanged, and the patient is receiving trial HCO3 infusion to reduce pressor requirements.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has improved slightly, but the patient remains minimally responsive with occasional grimacing and no corneal reflexes. The patient's head CT is negative, and the goal is to minimize sedative medications.
* Shock: The patient's shock has remained pressor-dependent, and the goal is to maintain a MAP of >55.
* Impaired skin integrity: The patient has a diffuse rash.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Worsening respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen if the patient's acidosis is not addressed or if the patient's pneumonia is not effectively treated.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can worsen if the patient's infection is not effectively treated or if the patient's immune system is compromised.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure can worsen if the patient's creatinine level continues to rise or if the patient's kidney function is not improved.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status can worsen if the patient's sedative medications are not managed effectively or if the patient's underlying condition is not addressed.
5. Shock: The patient's shock can worsen if the patient's blood pressure is not maintained or if the patient's cardiac function is compromised.
6. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity can worsen if the patient's rash is not effectively treated or if the patient's skin is not properly managed.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia can worsen if the patient's sodium level is not managed effectively or if the patient's fluid status is not monitored.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to improve the patient's oxygenation.
2. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat the patient's GBS sepsis, pneumonia, and HSV infection.
3. Fluid management: The patient is receiving fluid boluses and pressor therapy to maintain the patient's blood pressure.
4. Sedation management: The patient is receiving sedation to manage the patient's altered mental status, and the goal is to minimize sedative medications.
5. Nutrition: The patient is receiving enteral nutrition through a nasogastric tube.
6. Glycemic control: The patient's glucose level is being monitored and managed to prevent hyperglycemia.
7. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylactic antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy to prevent infection and thrombosis.

Overall, the patient's current condition is critical, and the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent worsening of the patient's condition.

   secondary to generalized HSV infection, the HSV DFA and culture from
   mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers to extubation include
   altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural

   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).

   off CO2 when he is being given bicarb
   - continue day 10 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the
   drug of choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours
   (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue day 12 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 8 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 yesterday, re-check lytes in
   the pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, consider
   giving another dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues to remain remain
   pressors-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.  UA was negative. Blood
   culture has been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No
   evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - wean down pressors as pt has evidence of digital ischemia now. Goal
   MAP 55 (given his very low diastolic), although it would still be ideal
   to get his MAP to 55 to adequately perfuse his brain for improvement in
   mental status
   - with ongoing pleural effusions and nl CVP, would attempt to maintain
   MAP with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have an anion gap, likely due to
   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly
   improved.
   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 26  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .

   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]

   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**]. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - transfuse one unit prbcs today cautiously given volume status
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   -continue to monitor
   -PM lytes
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, and multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis). He has been diagnosed with GBS pneumonia and sepsis. He has been treated with penicillin G and clindamycin, and his pneumonia is improving on imaging. He has also been diagnosed with HSV infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL and a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 94%.
* Sepsis: He is pressors-dependent on vasopressin and levophed, and his blood pressure is 118/33 mmHg. His central venous pressure is 8 mmHg.
* Metabolic acidosis: His anion gap is likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis. He has been given bicarbonate, and his pH has improved.
* Renal failure: His creatinine has slowly improved, and he has been diagnosed with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from hypotension from sepsis.
* Altered mental status: He has some stereotypical decorticate reflexes, and his mental status is unclear. He has been given thiamine and has had a CT head that was negative for any intracranial process.
* Anemia: His hemoglobin is 7.1 g/dL, and he has been diagnosed with anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. He has been transfused one unit of packed red blood cells.
* Hyponatremia: His sodium level is 107 mg/dL, and he has been given free water flushes q6h. His sodium level has improved.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to further decline in his oxygenation and ventilation.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis could worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and failure.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis could worsen, leading to further decline in his pH and potential organ dysfunction.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal failure could worsen, leading to further decline in his creatinine and potential need for dialysis.
* Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status could worsen, leading to further decline in his cognitive function and potential need for intubation.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to further decline in his hemoglobin and potential need for transfusions.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia could worsen, leading to further decline in his sodium level and potential complications such as seizures and coma.

ICU care plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilation and oxygenation as needed.
* Continue to treat his sepsis with antibiotics and pressors as needed.
* Continue to monitor his metabolic acidosis and adjust his bicarbonate levels as needed.
* Continue to monitor his renal function and adjust his fluid management and medications as needed.
* Continue to monitor his altered mental status and adjust his sedation and pain management as needed.
* Continue to monitor his anemia and adjust his transfusion therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor his hyponatremia and adjust his fluid management and medications as needed.

Family meeting:

The patient's family should be updated on his current condition and the potential medical complications that could arise. They should also be informed of the plan to discuss tracheostomy early next week and the need to monitor his condition over the weekend.

   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:  In the context of GBS pneumonia.  Patient has
   been treated with penicillin G and clinda, and his pneumonia is
   improving on imaging.  This respiratory failure could potentially be
   secondary to generalized HSV infection, the HSV DFA and culture from
   mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers to extubation include
   altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural
   effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV
   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).
   - on  AC currently, RR increased from 18 to 22 in an attempt to blow
   off CO2 when he is being given bicarb
   - continue day 10 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the
   drug of choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours
   (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue day 12 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 8 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 today, re-check lytes in the
   pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, can give another
   dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues to remain remain
   pressors-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.  UA was negative. Blood
   culture has been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No
   evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma

   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM

   MAP 55 (given his very low diastolic), although it would still be ideal

   mental status
   - with ongoing pleural effusions and nl CVP, would attempt to maintain

   .

   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly

   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 22  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .

   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR

   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly

   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome

   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine

   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools

   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have

   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2100-8-13**] 04:09 AM 35 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2100-8-3**] 01:53 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2100-8-3**] 12:53 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SC heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:  VAP bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR, cardioversion is OK
   Disposition: ICU care<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating skin lesions, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. He has been treated with antibiotics and antiviral medications, and his pneumonia is improving on imaging. The patient remains pressor-dependent and has evidence of digital ischemia. He has metabolic acidosis, renal failure, and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to his GBS pneumonia and may worsen if not managed properly.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely pulmonary, and the source of infection is likely GBS pneumonia. The patient remains pressor-dependent and has evidence of digital ischemia.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis. Bicarbonate therapy may help improve his acidosis, but further management is needed.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely due to hypotension from sepsis and may worsen if not managed properly.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to HSV encephalitis, sedation, and prolonged sepsis. Further management is needed to improve his mental status.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to GIB, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, or DAH. Further management is needed to improve his anemia.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely due to free water flushes, and further management is needed to correct it.
8. SVT: The patient's SVT is likely due to infection, volume depletion, and levophed. Further management is needed to prevent further episodes.
9. Skin lesions: The patient's skin lesions are likely due to GBS, generalized pustulosis, or a flare of psoriasis. Further management is needed to improve his skin lesions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antiviral medications as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with pressors and fluids as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's acid-base status and adjust bicarbonate therapy as needed.
5. Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with fluid and electrolyte management as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's mental status closely and consider further management, such as a lumbar puncture, if necessary.
7. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and further evaluation as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's electrolyte status closely and adjust fluids and electrolyte management as needed.
9. Continue to manage the patient's skin lesions with wound care and further evaluation as needed.
10. Update the patient's family on his condition and discuss goals of care with them.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, hospitalized at OSH for a probable drug rash, which progressed to acute respiratory failure, sepsis, GBS pneumonia, and HSV. He has been intubated and is currently in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98°F)
* Heart rate: 92 bpm (normal range 79-92 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 118/33 mmHg (normal range 102/28-122/41 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute (normal range 21-27 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 8 mmHg (normal range 7-17 mmHg)

The patient has a history of:

* Throat cancer treatment at OSH
* Diffuse rash and delirium during hospitalization at OSH
* Acute hypoxic respiratory failure, resulting in transfer to the ICU
* Diagnosis of GBS pneumonia and HSV
* Persistent respiratory failure, shock, acidosis, and poor mental status

The patient's current conditions include:

* Acute respiratory failure
* Shock
* AG acidosis
* Altered mental status (AMS)
* Hypernatremia (high sodium)
* Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count)
* Impaired skin integrity
* Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Nutrition: NovaSource Renal (Full) at 35 mL/hour
* Glycemic control: monitoring blood glucose levels
* Prophylaxis: DVT prevention with boots and SQ UF Heparin, stress ulcer prevention, and VAP prevention
* Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening respiratory failure
* Further deterioration of shock
* Progression of acidosis
* Development of septic shock
* Increased risk of VAP
* Skin breakdown
* Bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to SVT
* Renal failure exacerbation
* Hypernatremia worsening

It is crucial to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, hospitalized at OSH for probable drug rash, which progressed to acute respiratory failure, sepsis, and multiorgan failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: persistent and requiring high respiratory rates to ventilate.
2. Shock: ongoing and requiring pressors to maintain blood pressure.
3. Acid-base imbalance: AG acidosis, which is being managed with bicarbonate infusion.
4. Altered mental status: the patient is not responsive, does not follow commands, and occasionally opens his eyes to pain.
5. Acute renal failure: due to hypotension and ATN, with slow improvement in renal function.
6. Anemia: with a hemoglobin level of 7.1 g/dL, requiring transfusion.
7. Thrombocytopenia: with a platelet count of 113,000/μL.
8. Supraventricular tachycardia: present, but not specified as a primary concern.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: worsening hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Shock: progression to cardiogenic or septic shock, leading to further organ dysfunction.
3. Acute renal failure: worsening renal failure, potentially requiring dialysis.
4. Infection: progression of sepsis, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
5. Thrombocytopenia: bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
6. Supraventricular tachycardia: potentially leading to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
7. Hypernatremia: potentially leading to central nervous system symptoms, including seizures, coma, or death.
8. Impaired skin integrity: potentially leading to further skin breakdown, infection, or sepsis.

Given the patient's critical condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and radiological findings to adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:  In the context of GBS pneumonia.  Patient has
   been treated with penicillin G and clinda, and his pneumonia is
   improving on imaging.  This respiratory failure could potentially be
   secondary to generalized HSV infection, the HSV DFA and culture from
   mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers to extubation include
   altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural
   effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV
   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).
   - on  AC currently, has increased work of breathing; Rule out autopeep
   - trial of Pressure Support in order to decrease his work of breathing
   - continue day 10 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the
   drug of choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours
   (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue day 12 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 8 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 yesterday, re-check lytes in
   the pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, consider
   giving another dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues to remain remain
   pressors-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.  UA was negative. Blood
   culture has been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No
   evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - wean down pressors as pt has evidence of digital ischemia now. Goal
   MAP 55 (given his very low diastolic), although it would still be ideal
   to get his MAP to 55 to adequately perfuse his brain for improvement in
   mental status
   - with ongoing pleural effusions and nl CVP, would attempt to maintain
   MAP with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have an anion gap, likely due to
   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly
   improved.
   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 26  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**]. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal

t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:  In the context of GBS pneumonia.  Patient has
   been treated with penicillin G and clinda, and his pneumonia is
   improving on imaging.  This respiratory failure could potentially be
   secondary to generalized HSV infection, the HSV DFA and culture from
   mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers to extubation include
   altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural
   effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV
   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).
   - on  AC currently, has increased work of breathing; Rule out autopeep
   - trial of Pressure Support in order to decrease his work of breathing
   - continue day 10 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the
   drug of choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours
   (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue day 12 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 8 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 yesterday, re-check lytes in
   the pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, consider
   giving another dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues to remain remain
   pressors-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.  UA was negative. Blood
   culture has been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No
   evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - wean down pressors as pt has evidence of digital ischemia now. Goal
   MAP 55 (given his very low diastolic), although it would still be ideal
   to get his MAP to 55 to adequately perfuse his brain for improvement in
   mental status
   - with ongoing pleural effusions and nl CVP, would attempt to maintain
   MAP with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have an anion gap, likely due to
   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly
   improved.
   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 26  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**]. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - transfuse one unit prbcs today cautiously given volume status
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   -continue to monitor
   -PM lytes
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. He has been treated with antibiotics and antivirals, and his pneumonia is improving. However, he remains pressor-dependent, has evidence of digital ischemia, and is at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could potentially worsen due to his underlying GBS pneumonia, HSV infection, and pleural effusions.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis could progress, leading to further organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's anion gap acidosis could worsen, potentially leading to further organ damage and failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure could progress, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
5. Digital ischemia: The patient's digital ischemia could worsen, potentially leading to further tissue damage and necrosis.
6. HSV encephalitis: The patient's HSV infection could spread to his brain, potentially leading to encephalitis and further neurological complications.
7. Leukoclastic vasculitis: The patient's skin rash could be a sign of leukoclastic vasculitis, which could lead to further skin and soft tissue damage.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen, potentially leading to further fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
9. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia could worsen, potentially leading to further neurological and cardiovascular complications.
10. SVT: The patient's SVT could recur, potentially leading to further hemodynamic instability and cardiac complications.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics and antivirals as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's sepsis and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's metabolic acidosis and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's digital ischemia and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Consider further testing for HSV encephalitis, such as a lumbar puncture.
8. Continue wound care and consider further treatment for leukoclastic vasculitis.
9. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider further treatment as necessary.
10. Monitor the patient's hyponatremia and adjust treatment as necessary.
11. Monitor the patient's SVT and adjust treatment as necessary.
12. Discuss tracheostomy with the family and consider performing the procedure early next week.
13. Update the family on the patient's condition and discuss goals of care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. He has multiorgan failure, including renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He has GBS pneumonia and is being treated with penicillin G and clindamycin. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a pressure support mode to decrease his work of breathing. He has bilateral interstitial edema and pleural effusions on his chest X-ray.
* Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary, and he is being treated with antibiotics. He has a generalized HSV infection, which is being treated with acyclovir.
* Metabolic acidosis: He has a non-gap acidosis, and his bicarbonate levels are increasing his sodium intake, which is contributing to his volume overload.
* Renal failure: He has chronic kidney disease, and his creatinine levels are slowly improving. He is being supported with fluids and blood pressure management to ensure adequate perfusion of his kidneys.
* Skin: He has a desquamating rash, which is being treated with triamcinolone ointment and Aquafor. He also has an ulcer on his coccyx.
* Altered mental status: He has some stereotypical decorticate reflexes, which may be due to HSV encephalitis or prolonged sepsis. He is being monitored closely for any changes in his mental status.
* Anemia: His hemoglobin levels are stable, and he has received blood transfusions. He has anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, and his iron studies are normal.
* Hyponatremia: His sodium levels are improving, and he is being monitored closely.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: He may require tracheostomy, and his respiratory status may continue to deteriorate if his pneumonia does not improve.
* Sepsis: He may develop further complications from his sepsis, such as organ failure or disseminated intravascular coagulation.
* Metabolic acidosis: His acidosis may worsen if his bicarbonate levels continue to increase, leading to further volume overload and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Renal failure: His kidney function may continue to deteriorate if he does not receive adequate fluid management and blood pressure control.
* Skin: His skin condition may worsen if his infection is not properly managed, leading to further complications such as sepsis or organ failure.
* Altered mental status: He may develop further neurological complications, such as encephalitis or stroke, if his infection is not properly managed.
* Anemia: He may require further blood transfusions if his hemoglobin levels continue to decline.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the goals of care should focus on managing his respiratory failure, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, and renal failure, as well as monitoring his skin and mental status closely.

   yesterday improved to 137 yesterday evening and 136 this morning.
   -continue to monitor

   recent episodes in last 3 days.  Pt was hemodynamically unstable, SBP
   in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. Differential for etiology
   of SVT includes infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a
   beta1 agonist.

   instability

   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .

   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital due to respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, and multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis). He has been diagnosed with GBS pneumonia and sepsis, and is being treated with penicillin G and clindamycin. The patient has a complex medical condition with multiple comorbidities, including COPD, and is at risk for complications such as toxic shock syndrome, generalized HSV infection, and renal failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, and there is a risk of progression to multiorgan failure.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has metabolic acidosis, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
4. Renal failure: The patient has renal failure, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
5. Skin rash: The patient has a diffuse desquamating rash, and there is a risk of progression to toxic shock syndrome.
6. HSV infection: The patient has HSV infection, and there is a risk of progression to generalized HSV infection.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
9. SVT: The patient has SVT, and there is a risk of further deterioration.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The plan is to continue treatment for GBS pneumonia and sepsis, and to monitor for signs of deterioration. The patient's respiratory status will be closely monitored, and he will be treated with pressors as needed. The patient's metabolic acidosis will be managed with IV fluids and bicarbonate, and his renal failure will be managed with dialysis. The patient's skin rash will be managed with topical corticosteroids and antibiotics, and his HSV infection will be treated with antiviral medication. The patient's anemia will be managed with transfusions, and his hyponatremia will be managed with IV fluids and electrolyte replacement. The patient's SVT will be managed with cardioversion and beta blockers.

Goals of care:

The patient's goals of care are to improve his respiratory status, manage his sepsis, and prevent further complications. The patient's family will be updated on his condition, and a family meeting will be scheduled to discuss his care and any potential withdrawal of care. The patient's tracheostomy option will also be discussed with his family.

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. He has been treated with antibiotics and antiviral medications, and his pneumonia is improving on imaging. However, he remains intubated and pressors-dependent due to sepsis and multiorgan failure. His current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural effusion, and pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to GBS pneumonia, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation and pressors to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely secondary to GBS pneumonia, and he may require continued antibiotics and antiviral medications to treat the underlying infection.
3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely secondary to renal failure and lactic acidosis, and he may require continued bicarbonate therapy to correct the acidosis.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's renal failure is likely secondary to hypotension from sepsis, and he may require continued supportive care and diuretic therapy to maintain adequate renal function.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely secondary to HSV encephalitis, sedation, and prolonged sepsis, and he may require continued monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to GIB, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, and renal failure, and he may require continued transfusion therapy to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely secondary to free water flushes, and he may require continued monitoring and management to prevent further electrolyte imbalance.
8. SVT: The patient's SVT is likely secondary to infection, volume depletion, and levophed, and he may require continued monitoring and management to prevent further episodes of SVT.
9. Afib with RVR: The patient's Afib with RVR is likely secondary to infection and electrolyte imbalance, and he may require continued monitoring and management to prevent further episodes of Afib.
10. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis is likely secondary to liver injury from antibiotics and antiviral medications, and he may require continued monitoring and management to prevent further liver damage.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires continued close monitoring and management. His treatment plan includes continued antibiotics and antiviral medications, pressors to maintain adequate blood pressure, and supportive care to manage his respiratory, metabolic, and renal failure. He will require continued transfusion therapy to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels, and his electrolyte imbalance will require continued monitoring and management. His altered mental status will require continued monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration. His anemia will require continued transfusion therapy to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels. His hyponatremia will require continued monitoring and management to prevent further electrolyte imbalance. His SVT and Afib with RVR will require continued monitoring and management to prevent further episodes of arrhythmias.

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating skin rash, GBS pneumonia, sepsis, and multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis). He has been intubated for two weeks and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's current conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: GBS pneumonia, being treated with penicillin G and clindamycin; possible generalized HSV infection
* Sepsis: likely pulmonary, with blood cultures negative and no evidence of sinusitis
* Metabolic acidosis: non-gap, with bicarbonate therapy discontinued and LR used instead of NS
* Renal failure: slowly improving, with Cr slowly decreasing, and support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
* Altered mental status: possible HSV encephalitis, with CT head x2 negative for intracranial process
* Anemia: Hct stable, with GIB, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, and renal failure contributing factors
* Hyponatremia: improved from 133 to 137, with continued monitoring
* SVT: resolved, with possible etiology including infection, volume depletion, and levophed
* Afib with RVR: resolved, with cardioversion
* Transaminitis: resolved, with liver synthetic function good
* Hypothyroidism: uncertain, with levothyroxine discontinued in the setting of SVT

Potential medical complications:

* Pneumonia progression and worsening respiratory failure
* Sepsis and septic shock
* Metabolic acidosis and worsening renal failure
* Altered mental status and possible HSV encephalitis
* Anemia and possible GIB
* Hyponatremia and potential complications of electrolyte imbalance
* SVT and possible cardioversion
* Afib with RVR and potential complications of arrhythmia
* Transaminitis and potential liver dysfunction
* Hypothyroidism and potential complications of thyroid dysfunction

Recommendations:

* Continue antibiotic therapy for GBS pneumonia and sepsis
* Monitor and adjust pressors to maintain MAP and urine output >30ccs/hr
* Continue acyclovir therapy for HSV infection
* Monitor and adjust electrolyte levels, particularly sodium and potassium
* Continue to monitor and adjust renal function, particularly Cr and urine output
* Consider LP after clarification of goals of care
* Consider tracheostomy option and discuss with family
* Discuss goals of care with family and consider withdrawal of care if patient's condition does not improve.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. He has multiorgan failure, including renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 550 mL. His partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is 228 mmHg, and his partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is 36 mmHg.
* Sepsis: He is pressors-dependent on vasopressin and norepinephrine, and his blood pressure is being supported to maintain adequate perfusion of his kidneys.
* Metabolic acidosis: He has an anion gap acidosis, likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis, and is being treated with bicarbonate therapy.
* Renal failure: His creatinine level is slowly improving, and he is being supported with fluid resuscitation and diuretics.
* Leukoclastic vasculitis: He has a diagnosis of leukoclastic vasculitis, which may be related to toxic shock syndrome or a hypersensitivity reaction.
* Altered mental status: He has altered mental status, which may be due to HSV encephalitis, sedation, or prolonged sepsis.
* Anemia: He has anemia, which may be due to gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia of chronic disease, or anemia of chronic inflammation.
* Hyponatremia: He has hyponatremia, which is being monitored.
* SVT: He had a supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) episode, which was cardioverted and is being monitored.
* Transaminitis: His liver function tests are normal.
* Hypothyroidism: He was started on levothyroxine, but the diagnosis is unclear.

The patient's goals of care include:

* Updating his family on his condition
* Monitoring his progress over the weekend
* Discussing tracheostomy early next week
* Considering a lung biopsy if his condition does not improve

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation
* Development of ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Progression of sepsis and multiorgan failure
* Worsening of metabolic acidosis
* Development of further skin lesions or infections
* Potential need for lung biopsy or other invasive procedures
* Risk of cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and his disposition is ICU care.

 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow

   of SVT includes infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a

   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, and multiorgan failure. He has GBS pneumonia and sepsis, and is being treated with penicillin G, clindamycin, and acyclovir. He has also been diagnosed with renal failure, metabolic acidosis, and altered mental status. His skin condition has been attributed to toxic shock syndrome, and he has been treated with clindamycin and triamcinolone ointment. He has been intubated for two weeks and is being ventilated with pressure support.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and he may require prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to persist, and he may require continued treatment with antibiotics and pressors.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely to continue, and he may require continued treatment with dialysis.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely to persist, and he may require continued treatment with bicarbonate and other medications.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely to persist, and he may require continued treatment with sedatives and other medications.
6. Skin condition: The patient's skin condition is likely to continue, and he may require continued treatment with topical corticosteroids and other medications.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability is likely to continue, and he may require continued treatment with pressors and other medications.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing further infections, particularly pneumonia and bloodstream infections.
9. Bleeding: The patient is at risk of bleeding due to his coagulopathy and the use of anticoagulant medications.
10. Fluid overload: The patient is at risk of fluid overload due to his cardiac dysfunction and the use of fluids to treat his hypotension.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment with antibiotics, pressors, and other medications as indicated.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his fluid and electrolyte management as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's metabolic acidosis closely and adjust his bicarbonate and other medication dosages as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's altered mental status closely and adjust his sedative and other medication dosages as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's skin condition closely and adjust his topical corticosteroid and other medication dosages as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular instability closely and adjust his pressor and other medication dosages as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's infection risk closely and adjust his antibiotic and other medication dosages as necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk closely and adjust his anticoagulant and other medication dosages as necessary.
10. Monitor the patient's fluid overload risk closely and adjust his fluid and electrolyte management as necessary.

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:   Has GBS pneumonia, being treated with
   penicillin G and clindamycin; pneumonia appeared to be improving on
   imaging last week but worsening again.  Possibly has component of
   generalized HSV infection-- HSV DFA and culture from mini-BAL are
   pending. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental
   status, severe metabolic acidosis, infection, hemodynamic instability.
   TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at
   risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV infection from two sources (nasopharynx and
   lip).
   - on  AC currently, has increased work of breathing; Rule out autopeep
   - trial of Pressure Support in order to decrease his work of breathing
   - continue day 11 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (for
   GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]),
   - continue clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit
   toxin production
   - continue day 13 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 9 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if RMSF Neg,  will d/c doxy
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow
   .
   #) Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues on pressors--
   vasopressin and norepinephrine.  UA was negative. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so no need for CT sinus at this time.  Consider Toxic Shock
   Syndrome, given desquamating [**Month/Year (2) 5286**]
   - continue pressors, but titrate pressors to Urine output >30ccs/hr,
   independent of MAP; continue to monitor MAP
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - because of pleural effusions and normal CVP, electing to maintain MAP
   with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have acidosis, but appears to be
   more non-gap.  Was given bicarb previously, but bicarb is increasing
   his sodium intake, which is increasing his volume
   - d/c bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome.  Has new hemorrhagic bulla on hand, possibly
   indicating progression of the desquamating skin process.  Per derm,
   cefepime was d/c
d due to possibility of drug [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**] being the etiology
   of skin process.  Per derm, this is either GBS, generalized pustulosis
   (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of psoriasis. derm path from
   [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction: consider drug-induced or viral
   etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV
   [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Had some stereotypical decorticate reflexes
   yesterday. Possibility of HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**] sedation
   and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain, but
   will titrate pressors to urine output >30ccs/hr.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**] and 1 unit pRBCs [**8-15**].
   On admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac
   positive, anemia of chronic disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR
   infiltrate. Fe studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation.
   B12 and folate are normal. Patient also has renal failure which also
   contributes to his anemia.
   - repeat coags and get DIC labs
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued.  Hyponatremia 133 from
   yesterday improved to 137 yesterday evening and 136 this morning.
   -continue to monitor
   #) SVT:  pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT with no
   recent episodes in last 3 days.  Pt was hemodynamically unstable, SBP
   in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. Differential for etiology
   of SVT includes infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a
   beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - in setting of levophed restart, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family meeting tomorrow today
   - pt intubated x 2 weeks -- will need to discuss tracheostomy option
   with family in addition to goals of care and possible withdrawal of
   care
